name: NewYorker
text: "We have books all over our house, and I read in bed. I read at the beach. I read in the kitchen." A conversation with Dana Canedy, the first Black person to take over a major publishing imprint. https://t.co/Fx20jfWhCT

name: NewYorker
text: After the Black Lives Matter protests in late May, Joe Biden’s team did “make substantial moves,” a state representative in South Carolina said. But still, there “are areas where Vice-President Biden feels how he feels about the issue." https://t.co/0uhUsCnA7S

name: NewYorker
text: If the first wave of the virus in the Texas Panhandle was a story of rumor, stalled information, and essential work, the second wave was a story of reopening based on willful ignorance. https://t.co/VQmaDoWcDw

name: NewYorker
text: Elaine Stritch is magnetic in D. A. Pennebaker’s documentary about the recording of the original cast album for Stephen Sondheim’s “Company.” https://t.co/Zve9IuOuAx

name: NewYorker
text: In his first film, “The Killing Floor,” Bill Duke harnesses a directorial imagination that endows the very act of historical representation with political power. https://t.co/sLuPLT5dti

text: A cartoon by Trevor Spaulding. https://t.co/su3Rz1jjuW

text:
.@proseb4bros on voice acting, "blaccents," and racial signification in American animation.

name: NewYorker
text: "Instead of a priest, there’s a phone with which they can call their only black friend to apologize." https://t.co/NQjjd7tWv2

name: NewYorker
text: Plywood storefronts in SoHo bear the names of black men and women who were killed by police officers, flyers calling for investigations, quotes from James Baldwin and Malcolm X, and a poem by Langston Hughes. https://t.co/x6zeqdYHLc

name: NewYorker
text:
Whom should you put in charge of pulling the lever that will stop the runaway trolley from hitting a crowd of people? Easy: the guy who doesn’t believe in trolleys, right?
https://t.co/f5vFu5kakq

name: NewYorker
text: William Barr’s ham-handed firing of a U.S. Attorney captures the confusing combination of corruption and incompetence that has become a hallmark of the Trump Administration. https://t.co/8oI18k1I9e

name: NewYorker
text: During the 20th century, the press came to understand that its highest obligation was to the public it served. Of all the risks that trouble journalism today, the greatest may be that the media loses sight of this truth, @michaelluo writes. https://t.co/1LmMReYGC7

name: NewYorker
text: “Getting old is the second-biggest surprise of my life,” Roger Angell writes, “but the first, by a mile, is our unceasing need for deep attachment and intimate love.” https://t.co/EeY0QSvIxi

name: NewYorker
text: RT @michaelluo: I wrote a long piece revisiting the Commission on the Freedom of the Press, an extraordinary panel that convened in the 1940s, as democracy seemed imperiled, and wrestled with truth in reporting, the free market of ideas, and a free and responsible press.  https://t.co/FfX2bnEjpT

name: NewYorker
text: Michael Moorcock once wrote, “I think of myself as a bad writer with big ideas, but I’d rather be that than a big writer with bad ideas.” https://t.co/VVFSOHKqdT

name: NewYorker
text: The grim walls of the void mock Cube’s dreams of a better life. Someday, Cube will break through. https://t.co/giwlk4eKoD

name: NewYorker
text: The British actor on his new role in “Sometimes Always Never,” his abiding love for Mary J. Blige, and his personal style—"librarian chic." https://t.co/SdwQQqRcd2

name: NewYorker
text: In “Blood at the Root,” the poet Patrick Phillips offers a painful survey of his home town’s history, showing how Forsyth County, Georgia, viciously and proudly institutionalized white supremacy. https://t.co/piEq4LoO6T

name: NewYorker
text: The Willi Smith Digital Community Archive honors the achievements of black queer artists like Smith, and joyfully blurs the lines between scholarship, recollection, and gossip. https://t.co/UAgZx0CcRR

name: NewYorker
text: There is anger and exasperation all over HAIM’s new record, as if the women have grown tired of the contortions required to perpetuate their own cool-girl mythology. https://t.co/MjT9B3eUaB

name: NewYorker
text: “I go round and round in circles, feeling comfort and then feeling like I’m in a state of shock that I’m sharing this story, and then I laugh about it because it’s absurd.” Michaela Coel discusses her new TV show on this week’s episode of our podcast. https://t.co/2PfM3HgfSu

name: NewYorker
text: What if students were asked to take the lead in conceiving and organizing their education during the coronavirus pandemic? https://t.co/R2s6LGsDPo
